pageData.text:
Modeling population growth is an important aspect of environmental and social sciences.
In the first two activities, students simulate the population growth of an asexually reproducing organism without a and then of a bird population on an island with a set carrying capacity. In the third activity, they use birth and death dates to examine human demographics and . For the final activity, students use census data to visualize the age structure of world populations and gain insight into major historic events.

Paper, 6 sheets
Graph paper or graphing software
Computer with internet access
Cup of 160 counters, such as dried beans, dry rice grains, or pennies

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Simulation without Carrying Capacity - 15 minutes
Activity 2: Simulation with Carrying Capacity - 45 minutes 
Activity 3: Cohort Analysis - 120 minutes 
Activity 4: Population Pyramids - 30 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Carrying Capacity and Demographics

text: Compare logistic and <button class='glossary-text'>exponential growth</button>.
Examine the interactions between birth and <button class='glossary-text'>death rates</button>, and how they affect population growth.
Apply the concept of <button class='glossary-text'>carrying capacity</button>.
Use demographics to make predictions about the growth of national populations.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: What is Earth’s <button class='glossary-text'>carrying capacity</button> for humans? How will we know when we have reached it? Population researchers have been trying to answer these questions for decades because our population size makes such a difference in how we use Earth’s resources. Recent trends in population data have made us better able to answer these questions. The human population was estimated to have reached 8 billion people in late 2022<sup>1</sup>. While our population is still growing, the growth rate has slowed from a peak of over 2% in the 1960s to under 1% in 2020. This may not seem like a large drop, but when multiplied over the large human population, it makes a huge difference in how fast the population climbs. All the data suggest that this growth rate will continue to decline, and the human population will begin to flatten out, reaching its carrying capacity. Most estimates say the population will peak somewhere between about 9 and 15 billion. This wide variation is because human population growth is complex and depends on both natural factors, like resource and food availability, and societal factors, like education rates and advances in technology. If current trends continue, however, you may see the definitive answer to these questions within your lifetime.

1Roser, M., & Rodés-Guirao, L. (2013). “Future Population Growth”. OurWorldInData.org.
https://ourworldindata.org/future-population-growth

The Night Lights of Planet Earth by NASA/GSFC is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/wwworks/2712985992

pageData.desc: A map showing the lights of earth at night. Areas of high population density are brighter than other areas.
pageData.altText: A map showing the lights of earth at night. Areas of high population density are brighter than other areas.

pageData.text: Examining changes in populations over time is essential in many fields. Wildlife and fisheries managers need to make predictions about future population sizes to set acceptable hunting/catch limits. Economists want to know about human populations in different regions so they can make predictions about economic conditions. <button class='glossary-text'>Demography</button> is the study of factors that affect the rate at which populations, including human populations, grow.

pageData.subTitle: Growth Rate
pageData.text: Growth rate describes how a population is changing. It is affected by four main factors: birth, death, immigration (individuals moving into a population), and emigration (individuals moving out of a population). Mathematically, the growth rate (r) of a population can be represented as:
r = (births + immigration) – (deaths + emigration)

If increases due to births and immigration are greater than losses from death and emigration, then the growth rate is positive and the population is increasing. If the decreases from deaths and emigration are greater than increases from births and immigration, then the growth rate is negative and the population is shrinking. When the growth rate is zero, the population is holding steady.

pageData.subTitle: Population Growth and Carrying Capacity
pageData.text: In 1798, Thomas R. Malthus published a mathematical description of unlimited population growth. He argued that human populations continue to grow until limited by famine, disease, poverty, or war. In mathematical terms, the current size of a population is equal to the previous size of the population multiplied by the growth rate:
N(t + 1) = Nt r where Nt = the number in the population at time t r = the growth rate constant

This formula reflects unlimited if the value of r is greater than 1. If r is equal to 1, there is no change in the population size. If it is less than 1, the population declines to extinction. The formula depends on discrete intervals of time. To calculate growth over a continuous period, calculus is required.

In response to Malthus’s formula, other population scientists argued that wild populations frequently stay steady over time. They attributed a slowing of a population’s growth rate to a limitation of resources in the environment and suggested that population sustainability is due to a dependent on resources. Carrying capacity is the maximum sustainable size a population can reach within its environment. Pierre Verhulst first based a formula on the presumption that, as a population approaches the carrying capacity of its environment, the rate of growth is slowed. That formula is now generally presented as follows: N(t + 1) = Nt r [ (K - Nt) / K ] where Nt = the number in the population at time t K = the carrying capacity r = the growth rate constant

This type of growth is called <button class='glossary-text'>logistic growth</button>. The factors that contribute to this type of growth rate can be summarized as birth, death, immigration, and emigration. Individuals can enter a population only by being born into it or moving into it. Likewise, they exit only by dying or moving out.

Population-limiting factors may be density dependent or density independent for carrying capacity. Among the density-dependent factors are decreased resource availability (e.g., food, water, and space), competition with similar species, disease and parasitism, and buildup of waste. The most frequent density-independent factors are natural disasters or extreme weather.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the best interpretation of a population with a growth rate of zero?

options.text: The population size is holding steady.
The population has reached its carrying capacity.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A growth rate of zero means the rate of births and immigration is equal to the rate of deaths and emigration.

pageData.question: Growth rate is mainly affected by which factors?

options.text: birth rate, immigration, death rate, emigration
birth rate, death rate, carrying capacity
birth rate, death rate, Immigration, carrying capacity

It is affected by four main factors: birth, death, immigration (individuals moving into a population), and emigration (individuals moving out of a population). Mathematically, the growth rate (r) of a population can be represented as: r = (births + immigration) – (deaths + emigration) If increases due to births and immigration are greater than losses from death and emigration, then the growth rate is positive, and the population is increasing. If the decreases from deaths and emigration are greater than increases from births and immigration, then the growth rate is negative, and the population is shrinking. When the growth rate is zero, the population is holding steady.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Growth rate describes how a population is changing. It is affected by four main factors: birth, death, immigration (individuals moving into a population), and emigration (individuals moving out of a population). Mathematically, the growth rate (r) of a population can be represented as: r = (births + immigration) – (deaths + emigration) If increases due to births and immigration are greater than losses from death and emigration, then the growth rate is positive, and the population is increasing. If the decreases from deaths and emigration are greater than increases from births and immigration, then the growth rate is negative, and the population is shrinking. When the growth rate is zero, the population is holding steady.

pageData.subTitle: Population Demographics
pageData.text: Like all organisms, humans are affected by resource quality and availability. A human population will grow until the <button class='glossary-text'>carrying capacity</button> of its environment is met. For instance, archeological evidence indicates that drought conditions contributed to the collapse of the ancient Ancestral Pueblo (Anasazi) empire in the 12th and 13th centuries. Similarly, disease, drought, and exhaustion of soil nutrients are commonly cited as explanations for the rapid decline in population that marked the end of the Classic Maya civilization in the 8th and 9th centuries. Today, scientists examine a wide range of characteristics, or demographics, to study population trends. Demographics are shaped in part by resources. Demographic data includes numbers of births and deaths, age, rates of emigration and immigration, and many other statistics.

One way that demographers evaluate a population is to generate a graph called a <button class='glossary-text'>population pyramid</button>. This analytical tool shows how the total population is  subdivided into age brackets. A population pyramid can be used to predict future growth. Three population pyramids for 2016 are demonstrated in Figure 1, illustrating populations that are undergoing negative growth, rapid growth, slow growth, respectively.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Three examples of of population pyramids for 2016 showing male and female age cohorts, demonstrating negative growth in the United States, rapid growth in Nigeria and slow growth in Mexico.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Three examples of of population pyramids for 2016 showing male and female age cohorts, demonstrating negative growth in the United States, rapid growth in Nigeria and slow growth in Mexico.

pageData.text: The population pyramid is a period analysis that works from a snapshot of the population at one time. This can be useful for understanding a current situation but does not allow for particularly accurate projections of the future population.

The alternative is <button class='glossary-text'>cohort analysis</button>, in which the population is broken into cohorts that are then followed over time. This allows for greater accuracy, because parameters such as birth, death, and migration rates can be age specific. The effects of any variations, such as a baby boom, can be tracked over time.

A <button class='glossary-text'>cohort</button> is a group of individuals who do something (e.g., are born) in the same time period. The researcher decides on age groupings that can be split enough to reflect important life stages but are not so numerous as to overwhelm the computational capacity. A cohort of individuals moves together through various age groups over time and is often subdivided by sex.

The is the number of individuals who die within the set time period divided by the number of individuals who belonged to the cohort at the beginning of the time period. crude death rate = number of deaths / total population
The crude death rate is generally expressed in terms of 1,000 people. For example, if the crude death rate was 8.0 (per 1,000 people) this suggests that were 8,000 deaths in the entire population.

Likewise, the is the number of live births divided by the number of individuals. It can be hard to track marriages, divorces, deaths, and remarriages, so to keep from counting one child twice (for each parent), the birth rate is generally given as the number of births per each woman in the population. crude birth rate = number of births / total population

<button class='glossary-text'>Survivorship curves</button> (see Figure 2) show the attrition of a single <button class='glossary-text'>cohort</button> over the entire time that any members survive. The curves are generally set up as the number or percentage of surviving individuals versus age or time. Different organisms have different strategies for ensuring the next generation.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A color-coded graph demonstrating Type I (green), Type II (red), and Type III (blue) survivorship curves, showing the percent surviving from 100 percent to zero percent versus time
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A color-coded graph demonstrating Type I (green), Type II (red), and Type III (blue) survivorship curves, showing the percent surviving from 100 percent to zero percent versus time

pageData.text: K-strategists (named for the K in the equation) typically have fewer offspring but invest more energy in caring for the young. Elephants are an example of this strategy. Elephants give birth to only one calf at a time, and most have five years between calves. Calves stay under the protection of the mother and her herd until maturity at 10 to 15 years of age. Organisms of this strategy exhibit a Type I survivorship curve, having a slow decline at the beginning and middle of the curve (a low early mortality) followed by a rapid decline (most mortality among older individuals).

In the r strategy, organisms invest energy in producing many offspring in the hope that some will survive. Little energy is invested in the care of the offspring. Oysters, for example, spawn millions of eggs and sperm into a water column. Most of the eggs fail to be fertilized much less settle to grow into adult oysters. But the sheer number of offspring produced ensures the continuation of the species. Organisms that are r strategists usually have a rapid decline in their survivorship curve (a high mortality among the young) followed by a leveling off (a lower mortality for mature individuals). A Type III survivorship curve results from this kind of strategy.
Type II curves lie between these two extremes.

pageData.question: Which of the following organisms exhibits an r strategy for survival?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In the r strategy, organisms invest energy in producing many offspring in the hope that some will survive. Depending on the fish species, a few to millions of eggs and sperm can be spawned into a water column. Most of the eggs fail to be fertilized much less will grow into adults.

pageData.question: Which of the following organisms exhibits a K strategy for survival?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: K-strategists (named for the K in the carrying capacity equation) typically have fewer offspring but invest more energy in caring for the young.

pageData.altText: A procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. In activity 1, add beans to your sheet, double the number of beans on the next sheet, and repeat for each growth rate. Repeat with 4 different rates, then graph the data. In activity 2, place beans on a sheet, calculate the population in the next generation using given rules, and model population growth. Next, modify the death rate, repeat the simulation, and graph the data. Then proceed to Activity 3.
pageData.desc: A procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. In activity 1, add beans to your sheet, double the number of beans on the next sheet, and repeat for each growth rate. Repeat with 4 different rates, then graph the data. In activity 2, place beans on a sheet, calculate the population in the next generation using given rules, and model population growth. Next, modify the death rate, repeat the simulation, and graph the data. Then proceed to Activity 3.

pageData.altText: A procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, gather data from an assigned source, organize it into cohorts, and record demographic information for each cohort. Next, calculate the lifespan, average lifespan, lifespan frequency, crude death rate, and survivorship for each cohort. In Activity 4, open the US Census Bureau International Database, select a country, and sketch the population pyramid. Repeat this process for 4 total countries. Then, observe US population data over the last 20 years. Next, compare US and Russia population data. Finally, hypothesize and test the cause of the 1990s Russian population dip
pageData.desc: A procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, gather data from an assigned source, organize it into cohorts, and record demographic information for each cohort. Next, calculate the lifespan, average lifespan, lifespan frequency, crude death rate, and survivorship for each cohort. In Activity 4, open the US Census Bureau International Database, select a country, and sketch the population pyramid. Repeat this process for 4 total countries. Then, observe US population data over the last 20 years. Next, compare US and Russia population data. Finally, hypothesize and test the cause of the 1990s Russian population dip

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied
text: Printed Bird Island Map
Paper, 6 sheets
Graph paper or graphing software
Computer with internet access
Cup of 160 counters, such as dried beans, dry rice grains, or pennies

pageData.text: There are no safety concerns for this investigation.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a density independent population-limiting factor?
Which of the following is true of a population that does not experience limitations, such as food availability or predation?

options.text: It has reached its carrying capacity.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following variables represents carrying capacity in logistic growth calculations?
Which of the following tools shows how the total population is subdivided into age brackets?
Which of the following shows the attrition of a single cohort over the entire time that any members survive?
Some species have few offspring but invest more energy in their care.  What type of survivorship curve do these species tend to follow?
Which of these is NOT a factor that affects the logistic growth model of a population?
Which of the following best describes a species that exhibits a Type III survivorship curve?

options.text: It produces many offspring in the hope that some will survive.
It produces a few offspring, investing time and energy into their care.
It produces many offspring, of which it will care for a few.
It reproduces asexually or sexually depending on the environmental conditions.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activities completely.

In Activity 1, you will use counters to represent individuals in a population and model that population’s growth by adding counters for each successive generation. You will then repeat the simulation with different growth rates to compare the effect of growth rate on population size and graph your results.

typeBefore.text: This activity simulates the growth of an asexually reproducing organism, such as yeast or bacteria. The growth rate can be thought of as the number of individuals dividing in a given time period.

pageData.text: Write “time = 0” on one sheet of paper. Write “time = 1” on the next, and continue through “time = 5” on the sixth sheet.
Count out 5 counters, and put them on the paper labeled “time = 0.” This is your starting population. Record the number in Data Table 1.
Assume that the population growth rate (r) is 2.0. In other words, at each time interval, the population is double the size of the population in the previous period.

Calculate how many counters should be in the next time interval, and count them out onto the paper labeled “time = 1.” Record the new population number in Data Table 1. This is one iteration of this model. An iteration is one complete set of steps in a repeating sequence of those steps.
Repeat Step 4 until you have completed calculating and recording data through “time = 5.”
Return all the counters to the cup.

Repeat Steps 2 to 6 three more times, assuming the following population growth rates: r = 1.5, r = 0.7, and
r = 1.0.
If your calculation results in a decimal, round down to the next whole number regardless of the value. In other words, if you calculate 4.7, use 4 counters.
Return all the counters to the cup.
Graph your results for all four values of r. Put all four lines on the same graph for comparison. Be sure to label both axes and title your graph.

In Activity 2, you will use counters to represent individuals in a population and model that population’s growth by adding counters for each successive generation. You will modify the population each generation to account for changes in breeding pairs, number of offspring, <button class='glossary-text'>carrying capacity</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>death rate</button>. You will then repeat the simulation with a different death rate and compare the two trials by graphing your results.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will model and document the changes in a population of birds over time. This population does not meet the assumptions made in Activity 1, so this investigation takes into account several additional factors.

Birth Rate This model examines the bird population on a small island. Each nesting pair defends a number of territories. The more territories a pair can control, the more resources it has access to and the more chicks the pair can raise to adulthood. There are 32 territories on this island, each of which has the minimum space required to raise a single chick to adulthood. A given pair of birds can occupy from 1 to 4 of these territories and will have a corresponding number of offspring (1, 2, 3, or 4) each breeding season. As the population increases, competition will cause the ranges of the breeding pairs to shrink to the minimum size of 1 territory.
Death Rate Initially, assume a constant of 0.1. Then repeat the calculations using a death rate of 0.5.

Immigration and Emigration Strong prevailing winds prevent immigration to the island. However, adults that cannot find a place in one of the territories must emigrate to look for other places to live.

Carrying Capacity Each territory can support 3 birds—a breeding pair and a helper—and still produce 1 offspring. (A helper typically is an offspring from the previous breeding season that cannot get a territory of its own and stays to help its parents raise the next brood.) The of the island is 96 birds: 32 breeding males, 32 breeding females, and 32 helpers. If the bird population exceeds the island’s carrying capacity, the additional birds are forced to emigrate.

pageData.text: If you have not already done so, print a copy of the Bird Island map and obtain a cup of 100 counters.

Place 4 counters on the map. Separate the counters to create two breeding pairs, and then place each pair in the center of four small territories. These four territories represent the breeding range controlled by the pair. In Data Table 2, in the time interval row for zero, write “4” as the “Number in the population (N) at Beginning of Interval” column. For the first simulation, use a death rate of 0.1.
Perform the following calculations, and record the results in appropriate columns in Data Table 2.

text: Number of breeding pairs: Divide the population by 2. Single birds cannot reproduce. Remember that the island accommodates only 32 breeding pairs.

Number of offspring: Each breeding pair will have 1 offspring per territory in the breeding range controlled by that pair. A breeding pair can control up to four territories. Therefore, each breeding pair can have from 1 to 4 offspring. Example: If a breeding pair controls four territories, the pair will have four offspring.

<button class='glossary-text'>Birth rate</button> per female: Divide the number of offspring by the number of females. (In this instance, the number of females is equal to the number of breeding pairs plus half the number of helpers.)
Number of deaths: Multiply the death rate by the number of birds in the population at the beginning of the time interval (N). Round down to the nearest whole number.

Number driven off (emigration): Add the starting number of birds (N) and the number of offspring produced for that time interval. Then subtract the number of deaths as determined by the death rate. The resulting number is the number driven off. If the number is less than or equal to the carrying capacity (96), write zero as the number driven off.

Number in the population (to begin the next iteration): Add the starting population and offspring births, and then subtract the number of deaths and number of birds driven off. Record the result as the number in the population (N) at the beginning of the next time interval.
Population growth rate: Divide the number in the population for the next time interval (e.g., time interval 1) by the number in the population for the current time interval (e.g., time interval 0).

pageData.text: Use the counters to help you visualize what is happening during each iteration. This will help you keep track of how many territories each breeding pair controls. For each time interval:

text: Add counters to the island to represent the number of offspring produced in that interval.
Determine the total number of deaths and birds driven off from the time interval, and remove those counters from the map. Return the counters to the cup.

Redistribute the counters to represent breeding pairs. Breeding pairs prefer to spread out. If possible, spread out the pairs to allow them to control a range of multiple territories, up to a maximum of 4 territories. Note that once the population increases to a certain size, this will no longer be possible, and each breeding pair will lose territories until it controls only 1 territory. (As the population grows, the range controlled by each breeding pair will decrease.)
Repeat the iterations until the population of of birds remains unchanged for 3 consecutive time intervals.

pageData.text: Each territory can support a breeding pair and a helper bird—a maximum of 3 birds per territory. At carrying capacity, each territory will support a breeding pair and a helper.
Repeat the simulation using a death rate of 0.5. Assume the carrying capacity of the island remains at 96. Record your data in Data Table 3.

Graph the results of the two simulations, and note the differences over time between a death rate of 0.1 and a death rate of 0.5. Plot both lines on the same graph for comparison. Remember to label your axes and title your graph.

In Activity 3, you will perform a <button class='glossary-text'>cohort analysis</button> using birth and death data. For each <button class='glossary-text'>cohort</button>, you will calculate life expectancy, average life expectancy, crude <button class='glossary-text'>death rate</button>, and survivorship.
For this activity, you will obtain information on life expectancies and mortality rates. Your instructor will assign you one of the following sources from which to collect data:

text:
Visit a cemetery, and record the data from tombstones.
It is best to visit community cemeteries. Using specialized cemeteries, such as Arlington National Cemetery, will skew the demographic data.
Work with names taken from online databases of cemeteries.

pageData.text: Choose two groups to compare. You could choose two different birth (a group of individuals born within a defined timespan, usually 10 to 25 years). Alternatively, you may choose to look at males and females in the same birth cohort. All years of birth in this activity should be before 1910. If you are using online databases, you also may choose to compare two different regions of the country or world.

Collect data from your assigned source. A minimum of 50 individuals in each group is recommended, but more will yield better results. Record the year of birth, year of death, and gender in Data Table 4 for Cohort 1 and Data Table 5 for Cohort 2.
Calculate the age at death by subtracting the birth year from the year of death. Record this in Data Table 4 for Cohort 1 and Data Table 5 for Cohort 2.
For each cohort being examined, calculate the mean (average) lifespan for your sample data. Record it in Data Tables 4 and 5 as the average age at death.

For each cohort, calculate the number of individuals who died in each 10-year period after the initial birth year. For example, if the cohort is defined as individuals born between 1900 and 1910, determine the number of individuals who died before 1910, the number of individuals who died from 1910 through 1919, the number of individuals who died from 1920 through 1929, etc. Record this in Data Table 6 for Cohort 1 and Data Table 7 for Cohort 2.
Calculate the crude <button class='glossary-text'>death rate</button> for each cohort.

text: Divide the number of deaths by the total number of individuals at the start of the cohort.
Multiply the result by 1,000 to standardize the mortality rate to 1,000 individuals. This is the crude death rate. Record the death rate in Data Table 6 for Cohort 1 and Data Table 7 for Cohort 2.

pageData.text: Calculate the survivorship of each cohort.

text: Subtract the number of deaths from the total number of individuals in the cohort. This is the number of survivors. Record this number in Data Table 6 for Cohort 1 and Data Table 7 for Cohort 2.

To standardize the survivorship to 1,000 individuals, divide the number of survivors for the 10-year time period by the total number of individuals at the start of the cohort, and record the quotient in Data Table 6 for Cohort 1 and Data Table 7 for Cohort 2. The S1000 is a standard measurement of survivorship.
Graph the survivorship vs. time for each cohort on a single graph. Remember to label your axes and title your graph.

pageData.text: In Activity 4, you will look at data from the US Census Bureau's International Database to compare the <button class='glossary-text'>population pyramids</button> of different countries. You will then look at a country’s population change over time and use this to hypothesize about other countries with similar demographics and histories.

typeBefore.text: The United States Census Bureau keeps a comprehensive database of demographic data from around the world. Navigate to their International Database to perform this activity.

pageData.text: From the “Select by Country/Area”, select “India”.
Click “Ok”.
Sketch the graph and photograph it for upload to the Lab Notebook. Be sure to note the scale on each.
Record your observations about the graph in Data Table 8.
Repeat Steps 1-4 for the countries Italy, United States and Zimbabwe.
Return to the country page for the United States.

Near the bottom of the leftmost pane is the <button class='glossary-text'>Population Pyramid</button> Animation tool (Figure 3). Change the starting year to 20 years prior to the current year. Change the ending year to the current year.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: The population pyramid animation tool as it appears on the United States Census Bureau International Database website.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: The population pyramid animation tool as it appears on the United States Census Bureau International Database website.

pageData.text: Use the player at the bottom of the population pyramid graph to play the animated graph changes over time, or use the seek bar to manually change the graph. You may change the increment value in the Population Pyramid Animation tool to adjust how quickly the animation plays.
Make observations of how the population has changed over the past 20 years.
Repeat this procedure for Russia, selecting 1990 to 2010 as the year range.

Note the large dip in those who were in their late 40s in the early 1990s. In what other countries might you expect to find a similar pattern? Hint: Consider what major world events occurred during the lifespans of this . Make a prediction, and test your hypothesis.
There is no disposal or cleanup necessary for this investigation.

text: How does the shape of the curves in the graph above compare with the graph from Activity 1, where the growth rate was greater than 1? Identify whether each of these models is of exponential or logistic growth.
How did changing the death rate to 0.5 alter the growth of the population in Activity 2?
Explain what happens to the number driven off as the death rate increases.
What happens to the population in terms of carrying capacity when the death rate increases to 0.5?
What are some assumptions that the model in Activity 2 makes? Do you think these assumptions are realistic? Explain your answer.

text: Note the large dip in the population pyramid for Russia for individuals who were in their late 40s in the early 1990s. In what other countries might you expect to find a similar pattern? Describe your prediction. Was it supported by your testing? Explain.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Three examples of of population pyramids for 2016 showing male and female age cohorts, demonstrating negative growth in the United States, rapid growth in Nigeria and slow growth in Mexico.
Figure 2: A color-coded graph demonstrating Type I (green), Type II (red), and Type III (blue) survivorship curves, showing the percent surviving from 100 percent to zero percent versus time

A procedural workflow for activities 1-2 of this investigation. In activity 1, add beans to your sheet, double the number of beans on the next sheet, and repeat for each growth rate. Repeat with 4 different rates, then graph the data. In activity 2, place beans on a sheet, calculate the population in the next generation using given rules, and model population growth. Next, modify the death rate, repeat the simulation, and graph the data. Then proceed to Activity 3.

A procedural workflow for activities 3-4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, gather data from an assigned source, organize it into cohorts, and record demographic information for each cohort. Next, calculate the lifespan, average lifespan, lifespan frequency, crude death rate, and survivorship for each cohort. In Activity 4, open the US Census Bureau International Database, select a country, and sketch the population pyramid. Repeat this process for 4 total countries. Then, observe US population data over the last 20 years. Next, compare US and Russia population data. Finally, hypothesize and test the cause of the 1990s Russian population dip

data.title: Birth rate
data.content: The number of live births divided by the number of individuals

data.title: Carrying capacity
data.content: The maximum sustainable size a population can reach within its environment

data.title: Cohort
data.content: A group of individuals who do something in the same time period

data.title: Cohort analysis
data.content: An analytical tool in which the population is broken into cohorts and followed over time

data.title: Death rate
data.content: The number of individuals who die within the set time period divided by the number of individuals who belonged to the cohort at the beginning of the time period

data.title: Demography
data.content: The study of factors that affect the rate at which populations grow

data.title: Exponential growth
data.content: A growth rate that becomes more rapid in proportion to the growing total number or size

data.title: Logistic growth
data.content: A growth rate that decreases as population size approaches the carrying capacity

data.title: Population pyramid
data.content: An analytical tool that shows how the total population is subdivided into age brackets

data.title: Survivorship curve
data.content: The attrition of a single cohort over the entire time that any members survive
